name: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Male
sourceNote: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Male is the total number of male teachers in public and private secondary education institutions (ISCED 2 and 3). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross tertiary graduation ratio (first degree), female
sourceNote: Gross completion ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree. Female is the total number of female graduates in tertiary ISCED 5A programmes (first degree) expressed as a percentage of the female population of the age where they theoretically finish the most common first degree programme in the given country.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross tertiary graduation ratio (first degree), male
sourceNote: Gross completion ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree. Male is the total number of male graduates in tertiary ISCED 5A programmes (first degree) expressed as a percentage of the male population of the age where they theoretically finish the most common first degree programme in the given country.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross tertiary graduation ratio (first degree), total
sourceNote: Gross completion ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree. Total is the total number of female graduates in tertiary ISCED 5A programmes (first degree) expressed as a percentage of the total population of the age where they theoretically finish the most common first degree programme in the given country.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Student enrollment, tertiary, total
sourceNote: Enrolment in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Total is the total number of students enrolled at public and private tertiary education institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Student enrollment, tertiary, female
sourceNote: Enrolment in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Female is the total number of female students enrolled at public and private tertiary education institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Girls enrollment share (%), tertiary
sourceNote: Percentage of female students. Total tertiary is the number of female students at the tertiary education level (ISCED 5 and 6) expressed as a percentage of the total number of students (male and female) at the tertiary education level in a given school year.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Student enrollment, tertiary, male
sourceNote: Enrolment in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Male is the total number of male students enrolled at public and private tertiary education institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: School enrollment, tertiary (% gross)
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5 and 6). Total is the total enrollment in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6), regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: School enrollment, tertiary, female (% gross)
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5 and 6). Female is the total female enrollment in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6), regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total female population of the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: School enrollment, tertiary, male (% gross)
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5 and 6). Male is the total male enrollment in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6), regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total male population of the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Graduates, tertiary, total
sourceNote: Total graduates in all programmes. Tertiary. Total is the total number of graduates in all programmes in tertiary institutions.

name: Graduates in agriculture, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in agriculture is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied agriculture.

name: Graduates in agriculture (% of total graduates, tertiary)
sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in agriculture is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied agriculture.

sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in education is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied education.

sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in education is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied education.

sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied engineering, manufacturing and construction.

sourceNote: Total graduates in all programmes. Tertiary. Female is the total number of female graduates from all programmes at ISCED 5 and 6 tertiary institutions.

sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in health and welfare is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied health and welfare.

name: Graduates in health (% of total graduates, tertiary)
sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in health and welfare is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied health and welfare.

sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in humanities and arts is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied humanities and arts.

sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in unspecified programmes is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied unspecified programmes.

name: Graduates in unknown or unspecified fields (% of total graduates, tertiary)
sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in unspecified programmes is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied in unspecified programmes.

sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in science is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied science.

sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in science is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied science.

sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in social sciences, business and law is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied social sciences, business and law.

sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in social sciences, business and law is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied social sciences, business and law.

sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in services is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied services.

sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in services is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied in the services field.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Private enrollment share (%), tertiary
sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Tertiary is the enrolment in private tertiary institutions expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in tertiary institutions. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Tertiary education, teachers
sourceNote: Teaching staff in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in public and private tertiary education institutions (ISCED 5 & 6). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Teaching staff in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female
sourceNote: Teaching staff in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private tertiary education institutions (ISCED 5 & 6). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Tertiary education, teachers (% female)
sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Tertiary is the number of female teachers at the tertiary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the tertiary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross enrolment ratio.  All levels combined (except pre-primary).  Total
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. All levels combined (except pre-primary). Total is the total enrollment in primary, secondary and tertiary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of primary school age, secondary school age, and the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Public current education expenditure, primary (% of current education expenditure)
sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Primary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to primary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Public current education expenditure, secondary (% of current education expenditure)
sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Secondary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Public current education expenditure, tertiary (% of current education expenditure)
sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Tertiary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to tertiary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Public current education expenditure (% of total education expenditure)
sourceNote: Public current expenditure on education as % of total public education expenditure is the recurrent public education expenditure expressed as a percentage of total public expenditure on education (current and capital) in a given financial year.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Expenditure per student, primary (% of GDP per capita)
sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. Primary is the total public expenditure per student in primary education as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Share of public expenditure for primary education (% of public education expenditure)
sourceNote: Educational expenditure in primary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for primary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Spending on teaching materials, primary (% of primary expenditure)
sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in primary education. Teaching materials is the share of public current expenditure for primary education devoted to teaching materials.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Expenditure per student, secondary (% of GDP per capita)
sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. Secondary is the total public expenditure per student in secondary education as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Share of public expenditure for secondary education (% of public education expenditure)
sourceNote: Educational expenditure in secondary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for secondary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Spending on teaching materials, secondary (% of secondary expenditure)
sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in secondary education. Teaching materials is the share of public current expenditure for secondary education devoted to teaching materials.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Teachers' salaries (% of current education expenditure)
sourceNote: Educational expenditure on teachers salaries as a % of current education expenditures on public institutions. All Levels is spending on teacher salaries expressed as a percentage of the total current expenditures on education for all educational levels.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Expenditure per student, tertiary (% of GDP per capita)
sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. Tertiary is the total public expenditure per student in tertiary education as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Share of expenditure for tertiary education (% of total education expenditure)
sourceNote: Educational expenditure in tertiary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for tertiary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Public spending on education, total (% of government expenditure)
sourceNote: Public expenditure on education as % of total government expenditure is the total public education expenditure (current and capital) expressed as a percentage of total government expenditure for all sectors in a given financial year. Public education expenditure includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration, and subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Public spending on education, total (% of GDP)
sourceNote: Public expenditure on education as % of GDP is the total public expenditure (current and capital) on education expressed as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in a given year. Public expenditure on education includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration, and transfers/subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Public education expenditure, % of GNI
sourceNote: Public expenditure on education as % of GNI is the total public expenditure on education (current and capital) expressed as a percentage of the Gross National Income (GNI) in a given financial year. GNI is also referred to as Gross National Product (GNP). Public expenditure on education includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration and subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Public education expenditure per student (% of p.c. GDP), all levels
sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. All levels is the total public expenditure per student as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Prevalence of HIV, total (% of population ages 15-49)
sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV refers to the percentage of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV.
sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

name: Mortality rate, under-5 (per 1,000 live births)
sourceNote: Under-five mortality rate is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

name: Labor force with primary education, female (% of female labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with primary education, male (% of male labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with primary education (% of total)
sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with secondary education, female (% of female labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with secondary education, male (% of male labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with secondary education (% of total)
sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with tertiary education, female (% of female labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with tertiary education, male (% of male labor force)
sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force with tertiary education (% of total)
sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force, female (% of total labor force)
sourceNote: Female labor force as a percentage of the total show the extent to which women are active in the labor force. Labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Labor force, total
sourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment, female (% of female labor force) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment, male (% of male labor force) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Unemployment, total (% of total labor force) (modeled ILO estimate)
sourceNote: Unemployment refers to the share of the labor force that is without work but available for and seeking employment.
sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

name: Population growth (annual %)
sourceNote: Population growth (annual %) is the exponential rate of growth of midyear population from year t-1 to t, expressed as a percentage.
sourceOrganization: Derived from total population. Population source: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Report (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database..

name: Population, total
sourceNote: Total population is based on the de facto definition of population, which counts all residents regardless of legal status or citizenship--except for refugees not permanently settled in the country of asylum, who are generally considered part of the population of their country of origin. The values shown are midyear estimates.
sourceOrganization: (1) United Nations Population Division. World Population Prospects, (2) United Nations Statistical Division. Population and Vital Statistics Report  (various years), (3) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (4) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (5) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, and (6) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database.

name: Population, female
sourceNote: Population, female
sourceOrganization: World Bank estimates using ratio from UN World Population Prospects and World Bank's population.

name: Population, female (% of total)
sourceNote: Population, female (% of total) is the percentage of the population that is female.
sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: Population, male
sourceNote: Population, male refers to the total male population.
sourceOrganization: Derived from data on total population and population, male (% of total). Population source: (1) United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables).  Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm. (2) Census reports and other statistical publications from national statistical offices, (3) Eurostat: Demographic Statistics, (4) Secretariat of the Pacific Community: Statistics and Demography Programme, (5) U.S. Census Bureau: International Database, and (6) World bank estimates based on the data from the sources above, household surveys conducted by national agencies, Macro International, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and refugees statistics from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Male population percentage source: United Nations Population Division. 2009. World Population Prospects: The 2008 Revision.  New York, United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs (advanced Excel tables).  Available at http://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp2008/index.htm.

name: Population, male (% of total)
sourceNote: Population, male (% of total) is the percentage of the population that is male.
sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.

name: Gender parity index for gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for primary completion rate is the ratio of the female primary completion rate to the male primary completion rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females. The primary completion rate indicator is also referred to as gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for gross intake ratio. Primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross intake ratio. Primary is the ratio of the female gross intake ratio for primary to the male gross intake ratio for primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross entry ratio to lower secondary. General programmes. Total
sourceNote: Gross entry ratio to lower secondary. General programmes. Total is the total number of new entrants to lower secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of theoretical entrance age to lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross entry ratio to lower secondary. General programmes. Female
sourceNote: Gross entry ratio to lower secondary. General programmes. Female is the total number of new female entrants to lower secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the female population of theoretical entrance age to lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross entry ratio to lower secondary. General programmes. Male
sourceNote: Gross entry ratio to lower secondary. General programmes. Male is the total number of new male entrants to lower secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the male population of theoretical entrance age to lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for expected primary completion rate
sourceNote: Gender parity index for expected primary completion rate is the ratio of female expected primary completion rate to the male expected primary completion rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females. This indicator is also known as "Gender parity index for expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary."
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Enrolment in 5A tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Total
sourceNote: Enrolment in 5A tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Total is the total number of students enrolled at public and private 5A tertiary education institutions. ISCED 5A tertiary education is defined as tertiary programmes that are largely theoretically based and are intended to provide sufficient qualifications for gaining entry into advanced research programmes and profession with high skills requirements.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Enrolment in 5A tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Female
sourceNote: Enrolment in 5A tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Female is the total number of female students enrolled at public and private 5A tertiary education institutions. ISCED 5A tertiary education is defined as tertiary programmes that are largely theoretically based and are intended to provide sufficient qualifications for gaining entry into advanced research programmes and profession with high skills requirements.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Enrolment in 5B tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Total
sourceNote: Enrolment in 5B tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Total is the total number of students enrolled at public and private 5B tertiary education institutions. ISCED 5B tertiary education is defined as tertiary programmes that are practically oriented/occupationally specific and are mainly designed for participants to acquire the practical skills, and know-how needed for employment in a particular occupation or trade or class of occupations or trades. The successful completion of tertiary 5B programmes usually provides the participants with a labor-market relevant qualification.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Enrolment in 5B tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Female
sourceNote: Enrolment in 5B tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Female is the total number of female students enrolled at public and private 5B tertiary education institutions. ISCED 5B tertiary education is defined as tertiary programmes that are practically oriented/occupationally specific and are mainly designed for participants to acquire the practical skills, and know-how needed for employment in a particular occupation or trade or class of occupations or trades. The successful completion of tertiary 5B programmes usually provides the participants with a market-market relevant qualification.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

sourceNote: Enrolment in 6 tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Female is the total number of female students enrolled at public and private ISCED 6 tertiary education institutions. This level is reserved for tertiary programmes which lead to the award of an advanced research qualification. The programmes are therefore devoted to advanced study and original research and are not based on course-work only.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience.  Total
sourceNote: Percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience. Total is the number of new entrants to primary grade 1 who have attended some form of organized early childhood care and education (ECCE) program for the equivalent of at least 200 hours, expressed as a percentage of total number of new entrants to primary grade 1.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience.  Female
sourceNote: Percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience. Female is the number of new female entrants to primary grade 1 who have attended some form of organized early childhood care and education (ECCE) program for the equivalent of at least 200 hours, expressed as a percentage of total number of new female entrants to primary grade 1.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience
sourceNote: Gender parity index for new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience is the ratio of the female percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience to the male value for the same indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience.  Male
sourceNote: Percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience. Male is the number of new male entrants to primary grade 1 who have attended some form of organized early childhood care and education (ECCE) program for the equivalent of at least 200 hours, expressed as a percentage of total number of new male entrants to primary grade 1.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Expected gross primary graduation ratio. Total
sourceNote: Expected gross primary graduation ratio. Total is the total number of new entrants to the first grade of primary in a given year, regardless of age, who are expected to graduate from the last grade of primary education, regardless of repetition, expressed as a percentage of the population at the official graduation age from primary education in the same year. This indicator is calculated by multiplying the expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary education by the probability of graduation at the last grade of primary. This indicator is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Expected gross primary graduation ratio. Female
sourceNote: Expected gross primary graduation ratio. Female is the total number of new female entrants to the first grade of primary in a given year, regardless of age, who are expected to graduate from the last grade of primary education, regardless of repetition, expressed as a percentage of the female population at the official graduation age from primary education in the same year. This indicator is calculated by multiplying the expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary education by the probability of graduation at the last grade of primary. This indicator is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for expected gross primary graduation ratio
sourceNote: Gender parity index for expected gross primary graduation ratio is the ratio of female expected gross primary graduation rate to the male expected gross primary graduation rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Expected gross primary graduation ratio. Male
sourceNote: Expected gross primary graduation ratio. Male is the total number of new male entrants to the first grade of primary in a given year, regardless of age, who are expected to graduate from the last grade of primary education, regardless of repetition, expressed as a percentage of the male population at the official graduation age from primary education in the same year. This indicator is calculated by multiplying the expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary education by the probability of graduation at the last grade of primary. This indicator is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of female students.  Post-secondary non-tertiary education
sourceNote: Percentage of female students. name: Percentage female teachers.  Lower secondary
sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Lower secondary is the number of female teachers at the lower secondary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the lower secondary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage female teachers.  Upper secondary
sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Upper secondary is the number of female teachers at the upper secondary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the upper secondary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage female teachers. Post-secondary/non-tertiary
sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Post-secondary/non-tertiary is the number of female teachers at the post-secondary/non-tertiary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the post-secondary/non-tertiary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio.  Pre-primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio. Pre-primary is the ratio of female gross enrolment ratio for pre-primary to male gross enrolment ratio for pre-primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross enrolment ratio. Primary & Secondary combined. Total
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Primary & Secondary combined. Total is the total enrollment in primary and secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of official primary and secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross enrolment ratio.  Primary & Secondary combined.  Female
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Primary & Secondary combined. Female is the total female enrollment in primary and secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total female population of official primary and secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross enrolment ratio.  Primary & Secondary combined.  Male
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Primary & Secondary combined. Male is the total male enrollment in primary and secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total male population of official primary and secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross enrolment ratio.  All levels combined (except pre-primary).  Female
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. All levels combined (except pre-primary). Female is the total female enrollment in primary, secondary and tertiary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total female population of primary school age, secondary school age, and the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio.  All levels combined (except pre-primary)
sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio. All levels combined (except pre-primary) is the ratio of female gross enrolment ratio for all levels combined (except pre-primary) to the male value for the same indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross enrolment ratio.  All levels combined (except pre-primary).  Male
sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. All levels combined (except pre-primary). Male is the total male enrollment in primary, secondary and tertiary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total male population of primary school age, secondary school age, and the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio.  Lower secondary.  All programmes
sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio. Lower secondary. All programmes is the ratio of female gross enrolment ratio for lower secondary (All programmes) to the male gross enrolment ratio for lower secondary (All programmes). It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio.  Upper secondary.  All programmes
sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio. Upper secondary. All programmes is the ratio of female gross enrolment ratio for upper secondary (All programmes) to the male gross enrolment ratio for upper secondary (All programmes). It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for gross primary graduation ratio
sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross primary graduation ratio is the ratio of the female gross primary graduation rate to the male gross primary graduation rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. All programmes. Total
sourceNote: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. All programmes. Total is the number of graduates regardless of age in all lower secondary education programmes expressed as a percentage of the population at the theoretical graduation age for lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. All programmes. Female
sourceNote: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. All programmes. Female is the number of female graduates regardless of age in all lower secondary education programmes expressed as a percentage of the female population at the theoretical graduation age for lower secondary education.

name: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. General programmes. Total
sourceNote: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. General programmes. Total is the number of graduates regardless of age in general programmes of lower secondary education expressed as a percentage of the population at the theoretical graduation age in general programmes of lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. General programmes. Female
sourceNote: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. General programmes. Female is the number of female graduates regardless of age in general programmes of lower secondary education expressed as a percentage of the female population at the theoretical graduation age in general programmes of lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. General programmes. Male
sourceNote: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. General programmes. Male is the number of male graduates regardless of age in general programmes of lower secondary education expressed as a percentage of the male population at the theoretical graduation age in general programmes of lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. All programmes. Male
sourceNote: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. All programmes. Male is the number of male graduates regardless of age in all lower secondary education programmes expressed as a percentage of the male population at the theoretical graduation age for lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for gross graduation ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree
sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross completion ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree is the ratio of female gross completion rate. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree to the male value for the same indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gross outbound enrolment ratio. Tertiary
sourceNote: Gross outbound enrolment ratio. Tertiary is the total number of mobile tertiary students coming from a country/region as a percentage of the population of tertiary student age in their home country.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Technical/vocational enrolment in lower secondary (ISCED 2) as % of total enrolment in lower secondary (ISCED 2)
sourceNote: Technical/vocational enrolment in lower secondary (ISCED 2) as % of total lower secondary enrolment (ISCED 2) is the percentage of all lower secondary students enrolled in technical/vocational education programs including teacher training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of students who are enrolled in lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Technical/vocational enrolment in upper secondary (ISCED 3) as % of total enrolment in upper secondary (ISCED 3)
sourceNote: Technical/vocational enrolment in upper secondary (ISCED 3) as % of total upper secondary enrolment (ISCED 3) is the percentage of all upper secondary students enrolled in technical/vocational education programs including teacher training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of students who are enrolled in upper secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for adult literacy rate
sourceNote: Gender parity index for adult literacy rate is the ratio of female adult literacy rate to the male adult literacy rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Elderly (65+) literacy rate (%). Total
sourceNote: Elderly (65+) literacy rate (%). Total is the percentage of the population age 65 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, literacy also encompasses numeracy, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of literates aged 65 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Elderly (65+) literacy rate (%). Female
sourceNote: Elderly (65+) literacy rate (%). Female is the percentage of females age 65 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, literacy also encompasses numeracy, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of female literates aged 65 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for elderly literacy rate
sourceNote: Gender parity index for elderly literacy rate is the ratio of female elderly literacy rate to the male elderly literacy rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Elderly (65+) literacy rate (%). Male
sourceNote: Elderly (65+) literacy rate (%). Male is the percentage of males age 65 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, literacy also encompasses numeracy, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of male literates aged 65 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Inbound mobility rate.  Total
sourceNote: Inbound mobility rate. Tertiary. Total is the number of students from abroad studying in a given country, as a percentage of the total tertiary enrollment in that country.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: New entrants who have attended some ECCE programme. Total
sourceNote: New entrants who have attended some ECCE programme. Primary. Total is the total number of new entrants to primary education who have attended an early childhood care and education (ECCE) program.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: New entrants who have attended some ECCE programme. Female
sourceNote: New entrants who have attended some ECCE programme. Primary. Female is the total number of new female entrants to primary education who have attended an early childhood care and education (ECCE) program.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: New entrants to Grade 1 of primary education.  Total
sourceNote: New entrants to Grade 1 of primary education. Total is the number of pupils entering primary education for the first time.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: New entrants to Grade 1 of primary education.  Female
sourceNote: New entrants to Grade 1 of primary education. Female is the number of female pupils entering primary education for the first time.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for net enrolment rate.  Pre-primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for net enrolment rate. Pre-primary is the ratio of female net enrolment rate for pre-primary to the male net enrolment rate for pre-primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for net enrolment rate.   Primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for net enrolment rate. Primary is the ratio of female net enrolment rate for primary to the male net enrolment rate for primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for net enrolment rate.   Secondary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for net enrolment rate. Secondary is the ratio of female net enrolment rate for secondary to the male net enrolment rate for secondary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for adjusted net enrolment rate.  Primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for adjusted net enrolment rate. Primary is the ratio of female adjusted net enrolment rate for primary to the male adjusted net enrolment rate for primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Net intake rate. Primary. Under age (-1). Total
sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Under age (-1). Total is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education who are one year younger than the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the primary school entrance age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Net intake rate. Primary. Under age (-1). Female
sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Under age (-1). Female is the number of new female entrants in the first grade of primary education who are one year younger than the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the female population of the primary school entrance age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Net intake rate. Primary. Under age (-1). Male
sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Under age (-1). Male is the number of new male entrants in the first grade of primary education who are one year younger than the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the male population of the primary school entrance age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Net intake rate. Primary. Over age (+1). Total
sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Over age (+1). Total is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education who are one year older than the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the primary school entrance age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for net intake rate.  Primary.
sourceNote: Gender parity index for net intake rate. Primary is the ratio of female net intake rate for primary to the male net intake rate for primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Adjusted net intake rate (%). Primary. Total
sourceNote: Adjusted net intake rate (%). Primary. Total is the total enrolment in primary education of the official primary school entrance age, as a percentage of the population of the same age in a given school year. It is the equivalent of the age-specific enrolment rate of the official primary entrance age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Adjusted net intake rate (%). Primary. Female
sourceNote: Adjusted net intake rate (%). Primary. Female is the total female enrolment in primary education of the official primary school entrance age, as a percentage of the female population of the same age in a given school year. It is the equivalent of the age-specific enrolment rate of the official primary entrance age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for adjusted net intake rate. Primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for adjusted net intake rate. Primary is the ratio of the female adjusted net intake rate for primary to the male value for the same indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Adjusted net intake rate (%). Primary. Male
sourceNote: Adjusted net intake rate (%). Primary. Male is the total male enrolment in primary education of the official primary school entrance age, as a percentage of the male population of the same age in a given school year. It is the equivalent of the age-specific enrolment rate of the official primary entrance age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Over-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Total
sourceNote: Over-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Total is the percentage of the primary school age population (ISCED 1) that is over the official primary school age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Over-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Female
sourceNote: Over-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Female is the percentage of the female primary school age population (ISCED 1) that is over the official primary school age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Over-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Male
sourceNote: Over-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Male is the percentage of the male primary school age population (ISCED 1) that is over the official primary school age.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Outbound mobile students (students from a given country studying abroad). Tertiary
sourceNote: Outbound mobile students (students from a given country studying abroad). Tertiary is the total number of students from a given country studying abroad.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Out-of-school children of primary school age enrolled in pre-primary education. Total
sourceNote: Out-of-school children of primary school age enrolled in pre-primary education. Total is the total number of primary-school-age children who are enrolled in pre-primary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Out-of-school children of lower secondary school age. Total
sourceNote: Out-of-school children of lower secondary school age. Total is the total number of lower secondary school age children who are not enrolled in lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Out-of-school children of lower secondary school age. Female
sourceNote: Out-of-school children of lower secondary school age. Female is the total number of female lower secondary school age children who are not enrolled in lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Out-of-school children of lower secondary school age. Male
sourceNote: Out-of-school children of lower secondary school age. Male is the total number of male lower secondary school age children who are not enrolled in lower secondary education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Outbound mobility ratio (%). Tertiary
sourceNote: Outbound mobility ratio (%). Tertiary is the number of students from a given country studying abroad as a percentage of the total tertiary enrolment in that country.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of private enrolment.  Lower secondary. General programmes
sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Lower secondary. General programmes is the enrolment in private lower secondary general programmes expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in lower secondary general programmes. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of private enrolment.  Lower secondary. Technical/vocational programmes
sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Lower secondary. Technical/vocational programmes is the enrolment in private lower secondary technical/vocational programmes expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in lower secondary technical/vocational programmes. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of private enrolment.  Upper secondary. General programmes
sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Upper secondary. General programmes is the enrolment in private upper secondary general programmes expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in upper secondary general programmes. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of private enrolment.  Upper secondary. Technical/vocational programmes
sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Upper secondary. Technical/vocational programmes is the enrolment in private upper secondary technical/vocational programmes expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in upper secondary technical/vocational programmes. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Pupil-teacher ratio.  Lower secondary
sourceNote: Pupil-teacher ratio. Lower secondary is the number of pupils enrolled in lower secondary school divided by the number of lower secondary school teachers.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Pupil-teacher ratio.  Upper secondary
sourceNote: Pupil-teacher ratio. Upper secondary is the number of pupils enrolled in upper secondary school divided by the number of upper secondary school teachers.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Percentage of repeaters in primary. Grade 1. Total
sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in primary. Grade 1. Total is the total number of pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade as in a previous year, expressed as a percentage of the total enrollment in the specified grade. It is calculated by dividing the number of pupils repeating a given grade in a given school year by the number of pupils enrolled in the same grade in the same school year and multiplying by 100.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for % repeaters. All grades. Primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for % repeaters. All grades. Primary is the ratio of female percentage of repeaters in primary to the male percentage of repeaters in primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

name: School life expectancy (years).  Pre-primary.  Total
sourceNote: School life expectancy (years). Pre-primary. Total is the total number of years of schooling which a child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, assuming that the probability of his or her being enrolled in school at any particular age is equal to the current enrollment ratio for that age. For a child of a certain age a, the school life expectancy is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the levels of education specified. The part of the enrolment that is not distributed by age is divided by the school-age population for the level of education they are enrolled in, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education. The result is then added to the sum of the age-specific enrolment rates. The expected number of years does not necessarily coincide with the expected number of grades of education completed because of repetition.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

sourceNote: Gender parity index for school life expectancy. Primary to secondary is the ratio of female school life expectancy (primary to secondary) to the male school life expectancy (primary to secondary). It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: School life expectancy (years).  Primary to secondary.  Male
sourceNote: School life expectancy (years). Primary to secondary. Male is the total number of years of schooling which a child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, assuming that the probability of his or her being enrolled in school at any particular age is equal to the current enrollment ratio for that age. For a child of a certain age a, the school life expectancy is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the levels of education specified. The part of the enrolment that is not distributed by age is divided by the school-age population for the level of education they are enrolled in, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education. The result is then added to the sum of the age-specific enrolment rates. The expected number of years does not necessarily coincide with the expected number of grades of education completed because of repetition.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for school life expectancy.  Primary to tertiary.
sourceNote: Gender parity index for school life expectancy. Primary to tertiary is the ratio of female school life expectancy (primary to tertiary) to the male school life expectancy (primary to tertiary). It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: School life expectancy net of repetition (years). Primary to lower secondary. Female
sourceNote: School life expectancy net of repetition (years). Primary to lower secondary. Female is the number of years of schooling that a female child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, excluding years spent repeating grades. The indicator reflects the overall level of development of an education system in terms of the average number of years of schooling without repetition that can be offered to the school-age population, including those who never enter school. It is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the given level of education, plus the number of pupils of unknown age in the given level of education divided by the school-age population for that level of education, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education, minus the number of repeaters in a given level of education divided by the school-age population for that level, multiplied by the duration of that level of education.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for school life expectancy net of repetition. Primary to lower secondary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for school life expectancy net of repetition. Primary to lower secondary is the ratio of female to male vales for the indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Survival rate to grade 4.  Total
sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 4. Total is the share of children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 4. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Survival rate to grade 4.  Female
sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 4. Female is the share of female children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 4. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Gender parity index for survival rate to grade 4
sourceNote: Gender parity index for survival rate to grade 4 is the ratio of female survival rate to grade 4 to the male survival rate to grade 4. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 4. Male is the share of male children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 4. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

name: Gender parity index for survival rate to last grade of primary
sourceNote: Gender parity index for survival rate to the last grade of primary is the ratio of female survival rate to grade the last grade of primary to the male survival rate to grade the last grade of primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Female
sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Female is the share of female children enrolled in the first grade of secondary school who eventually reach the last grade of secondary school, regardless of repetition. To calculate this indicator, divide the total number of female pupils in the last grade of secondary education by the number of female pupils who originally enrolled in the first grade of secondary education, and multiply the result by 100. The survival rate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

name: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Male
sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Male is the share of male children enrolled in the first grade of secondary school who eventually reach the last grade of secondary school, regardless of repetition. To calculate this indicator, divide the total number of male pupils in the last grade of secondary education by the number of male pupils who originally enrolled in the first grade of secondary education, and multiply the result by 100. The survival rate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
